description.narrative:
In a region where securing Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) is especially challenging, Masarouna will mobilize the power of young people’s collective action in six Middle East and North Africa (MENA) countries to support their fight for greater freedom of choice and respect for their SRHR through new and innovative pathways for change. Our vision is that young people (YP) meaningfully induce sustainable change that will enable them to enjoy their SRHR. Tunisia is one of the countries where the Masarouna programme will be implemented.
Context: In 2019, 41.4% of MENA’s population was aged 15-39, making it one of the world’s youngest regions. In recent years, young people have demonstrated their ability to become main drivers for change in response to long-standing structural inequalities, rising authoritarianism and increased levels of conflict and fragility. Young people in MENA continue to face some of the most vocal conservative opposition to their SRHR. The problem that Masarouna will tackle is the perpetual obfuscation and the increasing weaponization of SRHR as a form of social control. This strips SRHR of the urgency it deserves, yet, we strongly believe fulfilling young people’s SRHR can have a transformative effect on sustainable development due to its connection with basic human well-being and gender equality. Strategic objective: Young people in six selected countries in the MENA region achieve more freedom to enjoy their SRHR in inclusive societies. Targeted group: Young people aged 18-35, in particular (unmarried) women and LGBTQI+. Activists and individuals will be mobilized as agents and drivers of change throughout the programme cycle.
The programme’s strategic objective and outcomes contribute directly to achieving SDGs 3 (health and well-being), 5 (gender equality) and 10 (reduced inequalities. The programme is fully aligned with the ICPD25 Nairobi statement’s call for renewed commitments towards women’s and Young People’s SRHR.
The Masarouna programme implements two main pathways of change:
1: Lobby and advocacy with young people for their SRHR The first pathway promotes greater accountability of governments to adhere to international SRHR standards, human rights frameworks and agreements; promotes young people’s active and meaningful involvement in policy agenda-setting and decision-making; and increases public awareness on SRHR, including through media engagement, aiming to create new narratives on SRHR.
2: Strengthening civil society and reinventing civic space A strong civil society can be a mobilizer, an amplifier of voices and a watchdog. With strengthened capacities, CSOs can create a sense of urgency around SRHR to push for sustainable change. CSOs need the space to play this political role, which Masarouna aims to reinvent by promoting the political activation and participation of young people and creating and strengthening alternative civic spaces, both online and offline. Working online allows for reaching young people at scale by circumventing gatekeepers and mitigating risks around censorship.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib registered in Tunisia in the end of 2011 and opened an office here early 2012. Oxfam#s work in the Maghreb is a multi country program comprising Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria and Libya. It supports local projects, is involved in lobby-work to take into account the interests of the poorest people, and campaigns to involve citizens in our work. It#s focus in the Maghreb is on social and political participation, gender justice and supporting sustainable livelihoods work. Four Oxfam affiliates work in the Maghreb:Oxfam Novib (The Netherlands), Intermon Oxfam (Spain), Oxfam Italy and Oxfam in Belgium. Oxfam has been working in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region for over five decades and over the past four decades promoting gender equality and supporting women#sright to participate and be represented in governance and decision-making structures and processes.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to basic social services

EO1 Young people and civil society are capacitated to advocate for safe, adequate and inclusive SRHR information and services
KI-6 # Women led CSOs/movements capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening seven different capacities under the topic of influencing and awareness raising on SRHR for young people. These are: developing an influencing strategy, youth-led influencing, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning, digital campaigning, working with traditional media, and influencing social norms. In general, all organizations appeared relatively confident in their capacities to influence and raise awareness on SRHR for young people. Only one organization indicated to have more capacity development needs than offers. The four organizations appeared most confident in designing an influencing strategy and conducting a public campaign. Influencing social norms appears to be a capacity that most organizations are confident in. Working with traditional media was the influencing capacity that stood out as an area with the most support needs, with all four organizations indicating a distinct need to strengthen their work. Investing in youth-led influencing and lobbying and advocating for policy and practice change are two areas that showcase a mixed picture: two organizations indicating a need to develop capacities, while the two others indicated an offer. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

description.narrative: KI-6 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening seven different capacities under the topic of influencing and awareness raising on SRHR for young people. These are: developing an influencing strategy, youth-led influencing, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning, digital campaigning, working with traditional media, and influencing social norms. In general, all organizations appeared relatively confident in their capacities to influence and raise awareness on SRHR for young people. Only one organization indicated to have more capacity development needs than offers. The four organizations appeared most confident in designing an influencing strategy and conducting a public campaign. Influencing social norms appears to be a capacity that most organizations are confident in. Working with traditional media was the influencing capacity that stood out as an area with the most support needs, with all four organizations indicating a distinct need to strengthen their work. Investing in youth-led influencing and lobbying and advocating for policy and practice change are two areas that showcase a mixed picture: two organizations indicating a need to develop capacities, while the two others indicated an offer. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

description.narrative: KI-6 # Youth led CSOs/movements capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people
KI-6 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people
EO2 Young people have increased knowledge and skills to claim their SRHR
KI-7a # Female young people reached with comprehensive, correct information on SRHR for diverse young people, facilitated by Masarouna (not including young people reached via social media only)

comment.narrative: Though the country is known to have a more liberal stance on SRHR and women rights in the region, conservative social norms have control over the more decentralized areas than in the center. Accessibllity to clinics is not common, minority groups dont have great access to support or information, and youth depend on few accessible groups for information. Public education and health programmes are barely covering SRHR and are based on conservative social norms by service providers. Also access to online SRHR information has been provided but minimal and does not always reflect the needs of, and has issues in reaching diverse young people through the right channels.

More young people in the country have better access to comprehensive and correct information on SRHR. For 2022, 75 young people (including 30 young women) will be targeted, with 50% belonging to non privileged groups.

description.narrative: KI-7a # Gender not specified young people reached with comprehensive, correct information on SRHR for diverse young people, facilitated by Masarouna (not including young people reached via social media only)

comment.narrative: Though the country is known to have a more liberal stance on SRHR and women rights in the region, conservative social norms have control over the more decentralized areas than in the center. Accessibllity to clinics is not common, minority groups dont have great access to support or information, and youth depend on few accessible groups for information. Public education and health programmes are barely covering SRHR and are based on conservative social norms by service providers. Also access to online SRHR information has been provided but minimal and does not always reflect the needs of, and has issues in reaching diverse young people through the right channels.

Masarouna partners in the country will organise several joint advocacy initiatives with/by/for diverse young people, mostly campaigns, that are linked with international days (like the 16 days of activism). It’s also the ambition to widen the scope in the coming years to decentralized areas, working with media and cultural CSOs. Based on a mapping activity conducted in year 2, national engagement may be widened.

comment.narrative: Though the country is known to have a more liberal stance on SRHR and women rights in the region, conservative social norms have control over the more decentralized areas than in the center. Also access to online SRHR information has been provided but minimal and does not always reflect the needs of, and has issues in reaching diverse young people through the right channels.

More young people in the country have better access to comprehensive and correct information on SRHR. For 2022, 75 young people (including 30 young men) will be targeted, with 50% belonging to non privileged groups.

description.narrative: KI-7a # Non-binary/other young people reached with comprehensive, correct information on SRHR for diverse young people, facilitated by Masarouna (not including young people reached via social media only)
EO4 CSOs working with young people have increased their organisational capacities and have increased their civic space influencing capacity (online/offline) on SRHR
KI-13 # CSOs/ movements, both women and youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' capacities in reclaiming civic space and strengthening partnerships. Most CSOs expressed a need for capacity strengthening in the following areas: widening (digital) civic space for young people working on SRHR; civic space risk mitigation and protection of staff, partners and people they work with; protection in digital space; and perception by, and relation with constituencies. Most partners stated they already have a strong capacity in strengthening and broadening partnerships. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

description.narrative: KI-13 # Women led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' capacities in reclaiming civic space and strengthening partnerships. Most CSOs expressed a need for capacity strengthening in the following areas: widening (digital) civic space for young people working on SRHR; civic space risk mitigation and protection of staff, partners and people they work with; protection in digital space; and perception by, and relation with constituencies. Most partners stated they already have a strong capacity in strengthening and broadening partnerships. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

description.narrative: KI-12 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' organizational capacities and capacities on cross-cutting themes. Capacity strengthening priorities most often indentified by partners are feminist MEAL, safeguarding (both prevention and response to inappropriate behavior), staff health and care, gender and power analysis, and mainstreaming gender justice and social inclusion. Most partners indicated to already have strong capacity on project management, project financial management, fundraising, feminist approach to SRHR and SRHR influencing, transformative leadership and working with specific target groups relevant to the programme. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

In 2022, an in-depth capacity assessment will be conducted, followed by the prioritisation of capacity needs with and by all engaged CSOs. Strengthened capacities will most probably include: Feminist MEAL; safeguarding on prevention of inappropriate behavior and responding to cases of inappropriate behavior; wellbeing; and project and financial management and stability.

description.narrative: KI-12 # Women led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities

comment.narrative: Masarouna partners are based and mainly working around the capital. There are not enough CSOs and social movements working with young people on SRHR, especially outside of the capital.

In 2022, an in-depth capacity assessment will be conducted, followed by the prioritisation of capacity needs with and by all engaged CSOs. Strengthened capacities will most probably include: Feminist MEAL; safeguarding on prevention of inappropriate behavior and responding to cases of inappropriate behavior; wellbeing; and project and financial management and stability.

description.narrative: KI-12 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities
KI-12 # Youth led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities
KI-13 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity
KI-13 # Youth led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity
IO 2.1 CSOs working with young people are empowered to form partnerships for collective advocacy on SRHR for diverse young people
KI-10b # Advocacy initiatives at subnational level in which CSOs/movements undertake collective action towards SRHR for diverse young people

comment.narrative: Currently the civic situation is unstable. There are a few existing initiatives advocating for SRHR, but mostly at national level. There is fear for the safety of women human rights defenders (WHRD) and feminist activists and the sustainability of thosefew existing advocacy initiatives. On the other hand, the COVID-19 situation looks stable especially with the end of lockdowns for now. Some young collectives and movements exist and are willing to challenge the status quo and to take collective action.

description.narrative: KI-10b # Advocacy initiatives at all other levels (national/international) in which CSOs/movements undertake collective action towards SRHR for diverse young people

comment.narrative: Currently the civic situation is unstable. There are a few existing initiatives advocating for SRHR. One such example is Ana Zada, a national campaign that also contributes to awareness raising and social norms inspective processes. There is fear for thesafety of women human rights defenders (WHRD) and feminist activists and the sustainability of those few existing advocacy initiatives. On the other hand, the COVID-19 situation looks stable especially with the end of lockdowns for now. Some young collectives and movements exist and are willing to challenge the status quo and to take collective action.

Masarouna partners in the country will organise several joint advocacy initiatives with/by/for diverse young people, mostly campaigns, that are linked with international days (like the 16 days of activism). It’s also the ambition to widen the scope in the coming years to decentralized areas, working with media and cultural CSOs. Based on a mapping activity conducted in year 2, national engagement may be widened.

description.narrative: IO 2.2 CSOs and social movements working with young people have adapted to shifting civic space and reclaimed space through movement building and stronger and more innovative alliances.
KI-11a # Cases at subnational level where CSOs/movements succeed in creating space for their demands and positions

comment.narrative: Masarouna partners are based and mainly working around the capital. There are not enough CSOs and social movements working with young people on SRHR, especially outside of the capital.

description.narrative: KI-11a # Cases at all other levels (national/international) where CSOs/movements succeed in creating space for their demands and positions

comment.narrative: The country has experienced a significant opening of civic space over the past 10 years despite attempts to increase controls over associations over the last five years. However, the baseline shows Masarouna partners lean towards an overall negative trend, despite some areas seen as less closed. Masarouna partners are based and mainly working around the capital. There are not enough CSOs and social movements working with young people on SRHR, especially outside of the capital.

Masarouna partners in the country can influence the law and policy agenda and influence the debate based on information received or exchanged through the digital platforms they have developed over the past 5 years. Through the focus on social norms, youth led, women led, and vulnerable groups can engage in partner´s public activities, discussions and artistic workshops with the possibility of exploring partnerships and/or joint activities in decentralized areas. Inputs from the contracted partners and potential partners will be key for identifying concerns and needs for their beneficiaries and local contexts, influencing the agenda of research and priorities for Masarouna. A more decentralized approach is required, with SRHR work done in more marginalized areas, as well as working more with youth led groups.

description.narrative: Improved policies: # cases where Oxfam/partners contributed to adopting /implementing improved gender sensitive policies, laws & practices to ensure women's & girls sexual & reproductive health rights (SRHR) by (sub)national governments or global actors

cases where Oxfam/partners contributed to adopting /implementing improved gender sensitive policies, laws & practices to ensure women's & girls sexual & reproductive health rights (SRHR) by (sub)national governments or global actors

Improved policies: # cases where Oxfam/partners contributed to adopting /implementing improved gender sensitive policies, laws & practices to ensure women's & girls sexual & reproductive health rights (SRHR) by (sub)national governments or global actors
pieces of evidence (documents, studies, videos, testimonies etc.) produced by Oxfam Novib and partners in support of development/adoption of alternative policies/approaches

pieces of evidence (documents, studies, videos, testimonies etc.) produced by Oxfam Novib and partners to support monitoring of practices and implementation of policies by governments and global actors
Partnership indicator
KI-16 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, engaged in Masarouna

comment.narrative: Oxfam in country partnered with three civil society organisations as part of the Masarouna Programme in 2021: 3 women led organisations, and 1 organisation that is both women and youth led. One of the engaged CSOs works towards achieving equality, human rights, and SRHR for marginalized groups and individuals. The mission of a second engaged CSO is to contribute to the response to STIs and to reduce its impact at all levels thus contributing national and global efforts to fight this epidemic. The third one works for the promotion of SRHR, and particularly for women to claim their SRHR. Oxfam in country (women led) focuses on four themes: gender justice and women’s empowerment, citizen mobilization for governance models and socio-economic policies that reduce inequalities, strengthening and supporting a free, open and influential space for civil society, and economic justice. Interventions these organizations work on include safe space, lobby and/or advocacy, public campaigning, (social) media work, coalition building, awareness raising, research, capacity strengthening, and piloting projects. Oxfam in country will implement some activities of capacity building and public engagements under the Masarouna programme.

Masarouna looks for its partnerships to be inclusive and the learning curve (on gender and social norms, SRHR, organizational, financial and managerial capacities, etc.) to be on the rise for all parties involved. We are also aware to raise any flags regarding safeguarding or the ability to commit to the ethos of Masarouna, while also keeping an open line of communication for any security concerns during the current political unrest and the ability of the partners to commit and deliver in terms of their mutual agreements and towards their beneficiaries.

Oxfam in country aims to seek subgrantees and additional potential partners starting in 2022. Partners that are not yet included that could be of great value if they would join the partnership include youth led and cultural and media organizations that work in decentralized areas, and have technological and innovative means and aspirations to deliver correct and progressive information on SRHR and safe spaces for diverse young people, and we intend to explore climate change oriented partners too. In 2022, at least two partners will be subcontracted by RNW Media as a result of the partner scoping visit finalised early 2022.

description.narrative: KI-16 # Women led CSOs/movements engaged in Masarouna

comment.narrative: Oxfam in country partnered with three civil society organisations as part of the Masarouna Programme in 2021: 3 women led organisations, and 1 organisation that is both women and youth led. One of the engaged CSOs works towards achieving equality, human rights, and SRHR for marginalized groups and individuals. The mission of a second engaged CSO is to contribute to the response to STIs and to reduce its impact at all levels thus contributing national and global efforts to fight this epidemic. The third one works for the promotion of SRHR, and particularly for women to claim their SRHR. Oxfam in country (women led) focuses on four themes: gender justice and women’s empowerment, citizen mobilization for governance models and socio-economic policies that reduce inequalities, strengthening and supporting a free, open and influential space for civil society, and economic justice. Interventions these organizations work on include safe space, lobby and/or advocacy, public campaigning, (social) media work, coalition building, awareness raising, research, capacity strengthening, and piloting projects. Oxfam in country will implement some activities of capacity building and public engagements under the Masarouna programme.
In 2021 , Oxfam in country (women led itself) partnered with two women-led civil society organisations as part of the Masarouna programme.

Masarouna looks for its partnerships to be inclusive and the learning curve (on gender and social norms, SRHR, organizational, financial and managerial capacities, etc.) to be on the rise for all parties involved. We are also aware to raise any flags regarding safeguarding or the ability to commit to the ethos of Masarouna, while also keeping an open line of communication for any security concerns during the current political unrest and the ability of the partners to commit and deliver in terms of their mutual agreements and towards their beneficiaries.

Oxfam in country aims to seek subgrantees and additional potential partners starting in 2022. Partners that are not yet included that could be of great value if they would join the partnership include youth led and cultural and media organizations that work in decentralized areas, and have technological and innovative means and aspirations to deliver correct and progressive information on SRHR and safe spaces for diverse young people, and we intend to explore climate change oriented partners too. In 2022, at least two partners will be subcontracted by RNW Media as a result of the partner scoping visit finalised early 2022.

For capactity strengthening on perception by & relation with constituencies, most organisations expressed aneed for capacity strengthening. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic.)
